component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: AddressCardComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component that renders the address information in a card component. <Address::Card @label="Delivery address" @recipient="John doe" @address="Fake street 123" @city="NYC" @country="USA" />

attributes.name: AddressCardComponent
attributes.description:
Component that renders the address information in a card component.

<Address::Card
 @label="Delivery address"
 @recipient="John doe"
 @address="Fake street 123"
 @city="NYC"
 @country="USA"
/>

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: ChangesetFormComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component that yields a Changeset instance of the underlying model that would be passed as a model argument to BS Form component. It looks up any validations for the changeset defined by the validators parameter. Simple usage of this component may look like this:  <ChangesetForm @model={{this.model}} @onSubmit={{fn this.save}} as |changeset form|> <form.element @name="username" @label="Enter username" /> </ChangesetForm>

attributes.name: ChangesetFormComponent
attributes.description:
Component that yields a Changeset instance of the underlying model that would be passed as a model argument to BS Form component.

It looks up any validations for the changeset defined by the validators parameter.

Simple usage of this component may look like this:

 <ChangesetForm
   @model={{this.model}}
   @onSubmit={{fn this.save}}
as |changeset form|>
  <form.element
    @name="username"
    @label="Enter username"
  />
</ChangesetForm>

accessors.name: validations
accessors.description:
Property getter that extracts the Changeset validations object from the Ember Containers if the validators argument is specified.

 <ChangesetForm
   @model={{this.model}}
   @validations="account"
   @onSubmit={{fn this.save}}
>
   ...
</ChangesetForm>

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: IconEbfComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: EBF Icon component that renders the icon from the EBF iconset. <Icon::Ebf @icon="ebf-user" />

attributes.name: IconEbfComponent
attributes.description:
EBF Icon component that renders the icon from the EBF iconset.

<Icon::Ebf @icon="ebf-user" />

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: InputsCounterComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component that is used to render a Bootstrap Input group component with a number input field, increment and decrement buttons. <Inputs::Counter @label="Size" @placeholder="Enter your size" @min="10" @max="20" @value={{this.value}} @onChange={{fn (mut this.value)}} />

attributes.name: InputsCounterComponent
attributes.description:
Component that is used to render a Bootstrap Input group component with a number input field, increment and decrement buttons.

<Inputs::Counter
 @label="Size"
 @placeholder="Enter your size"
 @min="10"
 @max="20"
 @value={{this.value}}
 @onChange={{fn (mut this.value)}}
/>

accessors.name: value
accessors.description: Input value, defaults to minimum value

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: LanguageSwitcherComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component that renders the Language switcher as a Bootstrap Dropdown component. It uses the locale service under the hood to extract the list of available locales, the currently active locale and to update it. The component has a single boolean argument showFlags to display flags before language label. Omitting this argument will hide the flags. <LanguageSwitcher />

attributes.name: LanguageSwitcherComponent
attributes.description:
Component that renders the Language switcher as a Bootstrap Dropdown component.

It uses the locale service under the hood to extract the list of available locales, the currently active locale and to update it.

The component has a single boolean argument showFlags to display flags before language label. Omitting this argument will hide the flags.

<LanguageSwitcher />

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: LayoutHeadlineComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component that uses Embers in-element helper that renders the contents inside the page-headline element in the application layout.

attributes.name: LayoutHeadlineComponent
attributes.description: Component that uses Embers in-element helper that renders the contents inside the page-headline element in the application layout.

accessors.name: destinationElement
accessors.description: Destination HTML element where the component body would be rendered.

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: LayoutWizardComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component that uses Embers in-element helper that renders the contents inside the page-wizard element in the application layout.

attributes.name: LayoutWizardComponent
attributes.description: Component that uses Embers in-element helper that renders the contents inside the page-wizard element in the application layout.

accessors.name: destinationElement
accessors.description: Destination HTML element where the component body would be rendered.

accessors.name: currentPage
accessors.description: Property that defines the current page

accessors.name: totalPages
accessors.description: Property that returns a total number of pages

accessors.name: totalResults
accessors.description: Property that returns a total number of results

accessors.name: hasNext
accessors.description: Checks if there is a next page

accessors.name: hasPrevious
accessors.description: Checks if there is a previous page

accessors.name: pages
accessors.description: Generates an array containing the page links range

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: ProgressBarComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component that renders the progress items.

attributes.name: ProgressBarComponent
attributes.description: Component that renders the progress items.

component:@ebf/design-system/components/.title: TableComponent
component:@ebf/design-system/components/.text: Component used to render the Ember easy-table component

attributes.name: TableComponent
attributes.description: Component used to render the Ember easy-table component

fields.name: height
fields.description: Height of the table. The default value is 65vh

variables.name: CONTENT_TYPES
variables.description:
HTTP Content Types

import { CONTENT_TYPES } from 'ember-cli-commons/constants';

CONTENT_TYPES.JSON === 'application/json; charset=utf-8';
CONTENT_TYPES.URL === 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded';

functions.name: disableBubbling
functions.description:
Helper that is used to stop event propagation.

You can use this helper on Ember on helper action callback:

<a href {{on "click" (disable-bubling this.action)}}>
 Some link
</a>

Or directly on an HTML element as an event listener:

<button type="button" onclick={{fn (disable-bubling this.action)}}>
 Button
</button>

template:docs/address.title: Address
template:docs/address.text: Address Form fieldset Component that can be used when you wish to render common address fields in your <ChangesetForm /> or <BsForm /> components. Show additional address field Show state field Card This component can also accept an address object, like so:

template:docs/alerts.title: Alerts
template:docs/alerts.text: Alerts Provide contextual feedback messages for typical user actions with the handful of available and flexible alert messages. This page shows some example usage of the <BsAlert> component. For the full documentation please refer to the Ember Bootstrap API Docs Simple example Available types

template:docs/breadcrumbs.title: Breadcrumbs
template:docs/breadcrumbs.text: Breadcrumbs This addon uses a template based breadcrumb management implemented by the ember-breadcrumbs addon. For the full documentation please refer to the addon docs. Home Documentation Breadcrumbs

template:docs/buttons.title: Buttons
template:docs/buttons.text: Buttons Custom button styles for actions in forms, dialogs, and more with support for multiple sizes, states, and more. This page shows some example usage of the <BsButton> component. For the full documentation please refer to the Ember Bootstrap API Docs Simple example Available types Outline buttons For a lighter touch, Buttons also come in outline-* variants with no background color. primary Sizing Fancy larger or smaller buttons? Add classes "btn-sm", "btn-lg" for additional sizes. primary primary Submit button Used internaly by the <ChangesetForm /> to display the submit button, but you can use in as you seem fit. It builds upon the <BsButton /> aggregated state where the <Loader /> is rendered when the state is pending.

template:docs/cards.title: Cards
template:docs/cards.text: Cards A card is a flexible and extensible content container. It includes options for headers and footers, a wide variety of content, contextual background colors, and powerful display options. Simple For the full documentation of a simple card layout please refer to the Bootstrap Docs Card title Some quick example text to build on the card title and make up the bulk of the card's content. Hover Use the Card component to add additional behaviour to your cards. Summary Use the Card::Summary component to show structured data in your cards. Options Products

template:docs/colors.title: Colors
template:docs/colors.text: Colors Convey meaning through color with a handful of color utility classes. Includes support for styling links with hover states, too. For the full documentation please refer to the Bootstrap Docs Primary colors Our primary palette is comprised of neutrals, white, and blue. These colors are present across most touch points from marketing to product. Grays Blues Secondary colors Our secondary palette is comprised of orange, red, green, blue and yellow. These colors are present across most touch points in products. Reds Oranges Yellows Greens Purples

template:docs/errors.title: Errors
template:docs/errors.text: Errors This addon comes with two components and an error-resolver service that can help you handle application runtime error and show user friendly error messages. Error display component Usualy used to display raw errors that would be resolved using the error-resolver. Error page Component that should be used in the application error route where the model needs to be an instance of ResolvedError Display additional links Usualy on error pages that should be a link that would redirect the user to the customer support page. To do this you can simply pass a @support argument with the Ember route name value of the support page. Apart from the support you can also pass an @home argument with the Ember route name to render a home link.

template:docs/footer.title: Footer
template:docs/footer.text: Footer The Layout::Footer uses a Bootstrap container to render child elements, if you wish to have a fluid .container you pass a @fluid={{true}} argument to the component. Advanced usage You can also choose to customize your own markup and contents for the footer Phone (123) 456 789 Email john.doe@ebf.com Address 123 Fake Street, Berlin, Germany

template:docs/form.title: Forms
template:docs/form.text: Forms Main form component exposed by the addon is the <ChangesetForm /> that builds upon <BsForm /> component and ember-changeset and ember-changeset-validations addons. In this page you can take a look at the examples and usage guidelines for form control styles, layout options, and validations for creating a wide variety of forms. You might also want to take a look first how forms are structured by Bootstrap be referring to the Bootstrap Form Docs. To know more how <BsForm /> component works and what are the options please refer to the Ember Bootstrap API Docs Concepts behind ember-changeset and how validations can be configured, please refer to the following docs: Changeset Changeset validations Simple form

template:docs/header.title: Header
template:docs/header.text: Header Main header for the application This component expects @label, @logo for branding. @logo is a path or url to the logo image. @label is the brand name to be displayed next to the logo. Additional content, such as navigation in the example bellow, is optional. This page shows some example usage of the <BsNav> component. For the full documentation please refer to the Ember Bootstrap API Docs

template:docs/headline.title: Headline
template:docs/headline.text: Headline Simple component that would render the <h1/> headline element with a subtitle. Simple usage Subtitle example Sizes You can configure the size of the headline by supplying the @as argument to any component, like {{element "h3"}}. Or you can specify it as a simple paragraph.

template:docs/inputs.title: Inputs
template:docs/inputs.text: Inputs Page contanining various input form components Counter Sizing Simply pass the input-group-sm or input-group-xl class to the component to size the counter component

template:docs/language-switcher.title: Language switcher
template:docs/language-switcher.text: Language switcher Component that renders the Language switcher as a Bootstrap Dropdown component. It uses the locale service under the hood to extract the list of available locales, the currently active locale and to update it. The component has a single boolean argument showFlags to display flags before language label. Omitting this argument will hide the flags.

template:docs/layout.title: Layout
template:docs/layout.text: Layout Components and options for laying out your UI, including wrapping containers, a powerful grid system, a flexible media object, and responsive utility classes. Grid EBF Design System uses Bootstraps grid system which is composed out of series of containers, rows, and columns to layout and align content. Its built with flexbox and is fully responsive. Below is an example and an in-depth look at how the grid comes together. For the full documentation please refer to the Bootstrap Docs Media The media object helps build complex and repetitive components where some media is positioned alongside content that doesnt wrap around said media. Plus, it does this with only two required classes thanks to flexbox. For the full documentation please refer to the Bootstrap Docs

template:docs/loaders.title: Loaders
template:docs/loaders.text: Loaders You can also pass a @label argument to show your custom loading text: Or define your custom markup as label: Loading state... Be patient while content is loading Promise Loader Handy component when dealing with asyncronous operations, like HTTP requests, that would show the <Loader /> component while the Promise is in a pending state. Depending on the promise state it would either show the <Errors/> component if the promise is rejected or it would render your defined component block template when the promise is fulfilled. Trigger successfull request Trigger unsuccessfull request Sizes You can customize the loader size by specifying the @size attribute to either sx, sm, lg or xl.

template:docs/modals.title: Modals
template:docs/modals.text: Modals Add dialogs to your site for lightboxes, user notifications, or completely custom content. This page shows some example usage of the <BsModal> component. For the full documentation please refer to the Ember Bootstrap API Docs Simple Alert Are you absolutely sure you want to do that??? Oh no, forget it! Yeah! Open modal Fullscreen Alert Are you absolutely sure you want to do that??? Oh no, forget it! Yeah! Open fullscreen modal

template:docs/navs.title: Navs
template:docs/navs.text: Navs Navigation components with default pills and tabs styles. This page shows some example usage of the <BsNav> component. For the full documentation please refer to the Ember Bootstrap API Docs Horizontal Home Navs Disabled Dropdown Home Nav Disabled Vertical Home Navs Disabled Dropdown Home Nav Disabled Simple Tabs Home Shop Disabled Dropdown Home Nav Disabled Tabs Home Navs Disabled Dropdown Home Nav Disabled Pills Home Navs Disabled Dropdown Home Nav Disabled Justified Home Navs Disabled Dropdown Home Nav Disabled

template:docs/progress.title: Progress
template:docs/progress.text: Progress Documentation and examples for using Bootstrap custom progress bars featuring support for stacked bars, animated backgrounds, and text labels. For the full documentation of a simple progress bar please refer to the Bootstrap Docs Progress Bar Striped progress bar Animated progress bar Progress Steps

template:docs/services/ajax.title: AJAX Service
template:docs/services/ajax.text: AJAX Service AJAXService is used to execute HTTP requests against a remote endpoints and builds upon ember-fetch addon. Usage To use the service in your components or controllers, simply inject the ajax service and call the request method. In this example we are using the <Await /> component that would execute the Ember Concurrent Task that would fetch data from the https://httpbin.org service. Request Interceptors AJAX Service also uses RequestInterceptor chain to provide additional configuration of each Request and Response that is executed through the service. Use the following Ember CLI generator command to create your generator: ember g interceptor logging This would create a new RequestInterceptor class that we can use to log each request and response. Open your Dev Tools Console and you would see that each request and response are logged when you click on the Execute request button above. Order of execution The interceptor can be ordered in the same way the Ember Initializers are, simple define the before and after conditions and the AJAX Service would the rest.

template:docs/services/cookies.title: Cookies service
template:docs/services/cookies.text:
Cookies service Ember Service used to manage Browser Cookies from the Application. Usage To read a Cookie value use the read method and pass the Cookie name as the first argument: class CookiesComponent extends Component { @service cookies; get cookie() { return this.cookies.read('cookie-name'); } } Then in your component template you can do the following:

My cookie value: {{this.cookie}}

Sync To update this state, simply invoke the sync method on the service. If the cookies are changed the state would be updated. Please note that AJAXService already syncs the Cookie service state each time a request is executed.

template:docs/services/destroyer.title: Destroyer Service
template:docs/services/destroyer.text: Destroyer Service DestroyerService is used to delete or destroy Ember Data models in a safe way by asking for a user confirmation via the Sweet Alert dialog. Once the user confirms that he wants to destroy the model, the destroyer service would invoke the DS.Model#destroyRecord method that would remove the model from the store. Usage To use the service in your components or controllers, simply inject the destroyer service and call the destroy method. In this example we are using the <PromiseLoader /> component that would show the loader while the save operation is executing. Helper You can also the destroy helper to invoke the DestroyerService#destroy method from your templates. There is no need to manually invoke it if your are dealing Ember Data models.

template:docs/services/error-resolver.title: Error resolver
template:docs/services/error-resolver.text: Error resolver Ember Service used to transform caught runtime errors into meaningfull messages that can be shown to the user. This service is usually used in Ember Routes to handle error actions. Best place for it would be in your Application Route where it would catch all error actions and show an error notifications using the ember-notify addon. The Ember notify container component is included by default in the <Layout /> component. If you do not use this component then you would need to add this to your application.hbs template. Trigger error Trigger not found error Trigger custom error

template:docs/services/locale.title: Locale service
template:docs/services/locale.text: Locale service Ember Service used as an adapter for ember-intl service that would resolve the locale from the SessionService. Usage

template:docs/services/persister.title: Persister Service
template:docs/services/persister.text: Persister Service PersisterService is used to invoke save methods on your DS.Model or on a Changeset instance. Usage To use the service in your components or controllers, simply inject the persist service and call the persist method. In this example we are using the <PromiseLoader /> component that would show the loader while the save operation is executing. Helper You can also the persist helper to invoke the PersisterService#persist method from your templates. There is no need to manually invoke it if your are dealing Ember Data models. Usualy this helper is used in conjuction with the <ChangesetForm /> where the on submit handler is invoking the persist helper:

template:docs/stats.title: Stats
template:docs/stats.text: Stats Component used to show stats as key value pairs, like address or product details. Usage Inline You can also show the stats inlined within a row like so: Custom yield value block If you wish to render a <LinkTo /> component or customize your markup for the value, you can do so like this:

template:docs/themes.title: Themes
template:docs/themes.text: Themes EBF Design System comes with multiple themes that can be used in the application. The default theme is the ebf theme but you can easily configure your application to use a different or both depending on the user session. Here you can see the available themes and how they look like, click on the dropdown item to select a theme. Available themes ebf telekom Single theme configuration To use one theme simply import the desired theme scss file in your app.scss file: @import 'ebf-design-system/ebf'; Mutliple theme configuration In case you would like to support multiple themes you would need to configure your application to generate multiple CSS files in the Ember CLI build. Create the ebf.scss and telekom.scss files in your styles app folder with matching theme imports. /* styles/ebf.scss */ @import 'ebf-design-system/ebf'; /* styles/telekom.scss */ @import 'ebf-design-system/telekom'; Remove the application stylesheet from your index.html as it would be loaded by the theme-manager in the Application route. <link integrity="" rel="stylesheet" href="{{rootURL}}assets/your-app-name.css"> Configure the output paths of the compiled CSS files in your ember-cli-build.js file like so: const EmberApp = require('ember-cli/lib/broccoli/ember-app'); module.exports = function(defaults) { const app = new EmberApp(defaults, { outputPaths: { app: { css: { telekom: '/assets/telekom.css', ebf: '/assets/ebf.css', // would be the default theme }, }, }, }); return app.toTree(); }; Add the theme configuration in your config/environment.js file so that the theme-manager service can load them in runtime depending on the current session state. 'use strict'; module.exports = function(environment) { let ENV = { ..., themes: [{ name: 'ebf', default: true, // mark ebf as default to load this theme in case session is not present }, { name: 'telekom', }], .... }; } Once you are done with the configuration you would need to two things in your Application router: restore the session setup the theme based on the session Best place to do this is in the Application route before model hook as this would force the application to render the application-loading template while the session and theme are restored and setup. import Route from '@ember/routing/route'; import { inject as service } from '@ember/service'; export default class ApplicationRoute extends Route { @service('session') session; @service('theme-manager') manager; async beforeModel() { try { await this.session.restore(); await this.manager.setup(); } catch (e) { console.error('Failed to load theme', e); } } }

template:docs/typography.title: Typography
template:docs/typography.text: Typography Documentation and examples for typography, including global settings, headings, body text, lists, and more. For the full documentation please refer to the Bootstrap Docs Heading Display Lead Paragraph Inline Text Elements

template:docs/usage.title: Usage
template:docs/usage.text: Usage Requirements To use EBF Design System, your addon must have a devDependency of Ember v2.8 or higher. Install To install the Ember CLI Addon you can use the following command: ember install @ebf/ember-cli-design-system If you wish to use only the SASS or CSS files without Ember components use this NPM library instead: npm install @ebf/design-system

template:project.text: Docs index Docs Headline Docs WIZARD
